messages.text:
Where to begin?
1. <@U66SGEWAC> saved my ass (again), helping me fix a bunch of issues I had with plotting and serving things off of a Raspberry Pi. 
2. I installed Julia 1.3.1 (cause that's what can run on Raspbian 32bit) on that RPI and everything just worked! I think I missed the new named-tuple thing `(; this, thing)`, like once. Other than that, everything literally just worked!
3. People here are so eager to help, it's just so nice. Also, it's the only way I can get so much done. 
So thank you all for everything!!!

elements.text: Where to begin?
saved my ass (again), helping me fix a bunch of issues I had with plotting and serving things off of a Raspberry Pi.
I installed Julia 1.3.1 (cause that's what can run on Raspbian 32bit) on that RPI and everything just worked! I think I missed the new named-tuple thing
(; this, thing)
, like once. Other than that, everything literally just worked!
People here are so eager to help, it's just so nice. Also, it's the only way I can get so much done.
So thank you all for everything!!!

messages.text: <@U681ELA87> and all the other contributors who made Arrow.jl an official Apache project. Bringing zero copy data transfers to the language!

elements.text: and all the other contributors who made Arrow.jl an official Apache project. Bringing zero copy data transfers to the language!

messages.text: I am also grateful for Arrow.jl and <@U681ELA87>’s work on it, but I would like to point out that there was already plenty of zero copy data transfers all over Julia, because the language does not suffer from the limitations of the language(s) (one language very much in particular) that arrow was originally designed to overcome  (though, of course, now we can enjoy zero-copy with all the other stuff that works with arrow, which we certainly did not have before)

messages.text: writing julia code is just _so fulfilling_ sometimes. I had prepared a branch in a project to implement a corner case for one of my algorithms, but after trying it I realized that my upstream code was generic enough to Just Work^TM. I appreciate all the effort that goes into the language that enables that little *magic* feeling. It’s truly energizing and gives me so much motivation to create more and do more.

so fulfilling

I appreciate all the effort that goes into the language that enables that little *magic* feeling. It’s truly energizing and gives me so much motivation to create more and do more.

messages.text: This blog is very helpful! <https://www.maximiliankoehler.de/posts/pluto-server/>

attachments.title: How To: Set Up a Pluto.jl Server for Teaching Purposes
attachments.text: I want to share what my colleague Dennis Ogiermann and me learnt while setting up a server that I’m going to use for a teaching adventure with Julia. I’ll teach exercises in the course “Basics of FEM” for mechanical engineers. The problems The mechanical engineering students have no or little experience with programming (and very likely no experience with a terminal) There is no time to teach them in depth programming, terminal handling, etc.

attachments.text: I just had this fun one liner. Let say you wish to do polynomial interpolation given an array v and f.(v) == w, you wish to find f(x). ([y^i for y in v, i in 0:length(v)] \ w)'*[x^i for i in 0:length(v)-1]

messages.text: I've been holding off of trying out 1.6 because I wanted to wait for a beta release, but I couldn't stop myself and built it locally (and because it seems closeish now) - and wowzers, was it worth it! There are so many pretty colors in `@code_llvm` and `@code_native` now, precompilation is :gotta-go-fast:  and all in all it feels really snappy and fast. Much :heart:  to everyone who contributed!

messages.text:
I want to declare my love for the Julia REPL. Looking at my old Python code, I was horrified to find that used Jupyter Notebooks to program, and then copy-pasted the content into `.py` files. I did that because I like interactive workflows, and Python's REPL is abysmal.

Having a good REPL is one of those quality of life-things that *could* have been swept under the rug as "not important". In contrast, Julia has implemented *so many* small things that make the REPL an absolute joy. All of you who contributed to that are much appreciated.

elements.text: I want to declare my love for the Julia REPL. Looking at my old Python code, I was horrified to find that used Jupyter Notebooks to program, and then copy-pasted the content into

messages.text:
just discovered ReplMaker.jl (<https://github.com/MasonProtter/ReplMaker.jl>). It's amazing that it makes it possible to get a whole new (useful) repl mode in one line of code! (thanks, <@U8D9768Q6> and contributors) e.g.
```julia> using ReplMaker

julia> initrepl(apropos; prompt_text="search> ", prompt_color=:magenta, start_key=')', mode_name="search_mode")
REPL mode search_mode initialized. Press ) to enter and backspace to exit.
"Prompt(\"search> \",...)"

search> drop
Base.dropdims
Base.Iterators.takewhile
Base.Iterators.drop
Base.Iterators.dropwhile
Base.Filesystem.joinpath
SparseArrays.dropzeros!
SparseArrays.sparse
SparseArrays.dropzeros
SparseArrays.dropstored!
SparseArrays.droptol!```

"Prompt(\"search> \",...)"

search> drop

SparseArrays.droptol!

messages.text:
excerpt from summary of the PR above:
> except `;;` may appear at the end of a line to provide a line break which Jeff Bezanson will pretend doesn't exist
I like to imagine that there is a little Jeff embedded in every distribution of Julia. When you make method ambiguity or dimension mismatch errors, lil' J just throws up his arms in exasperation.

messages.text: <@U66GD0880>, <@U67461GUB> and the Julia community in general for their explosive initiative and creativity. I was wondering with <@U8MPCDJAY> in <#CB8A1RNCE|static-compilation> why MKL.jl has stopped working from 1.6 onward, and timidly pinged <@U66GD0880> to ask if we can now distribute MKL-compiled Julia binaries, who pinged <@U67461GUB>, who, together with <@U67D54KS8> and <@U8MPCDJAY>, concluded that what we need is a way to switch arbitrary BLAS libraries on the fly, with performance and in any platform. They then proceeded, during the following few hours, to exchange around a hundred slack messages, opened a new repo with a proof of concept for a switchable BLAS design and began to explore how to link Julia against it to be able to activate the MKL library on the fly. It was fascinating to watch. I am so floored by this community!

They then proceeded, during the following few hours, to exchange around a hundred slack messages, opened a new repo with a proof of concept for a switchable BLAS design and began to explore how to link Julia against it to be able to activate the MKL library on the fly. It was fascinating to watch. I am so floored by this community!

elements.text: I appreciate Julia never ceasing to amaze me:
(shoutout to
for pointing this out)

messages.text:
<@U681ELA87> and CSV.jl.

I just got sent a truly *horrendous* csv file (everything quoted including numerical columns, a mix of empty, `""` and `"NA"` to indicate missing values, some rows missing columns, probably more that I haven't found), and CSV.jl parsed it incredibly gracefully. Not even in a DWIM way - there were a couple of places where it was ambiguous and it just fell back to parsing as string. Just :italian-chef-kiss:

messages.text: yeah, CSV.jl is amazing.  It's even in a way, kind of ironic that Julia has arguably the best CSV parser there is (at least the best on less than enormous files), since Julia users are more likely to despise csv files.  I've been using CSV.jl at work all the time for quite a while now, because I need csv's so that my colleagues can read my output with AWS athena

messages.text: Recently I had a file where tidyverse's `read_csv` failed because the column was empty for rows at the top of the file, so the type was detected incorrectly. CSV.jl handled it just fine.

elements.text: Recently I had a file where tidyverse's
read_csv
failed because the column was empty for rows at the top of the file, so the type was detected incorrectly. CSV.jl handled it just fine.

messages.text: I do also very much appreciate how ever since I’ve been involved with the Julia community (almost 6 years now!), <@U681ELA87> has been tirelessly working on many of the parts that weren’t so interesting to many of the scientists / mathematicians (even though they often depended on such things as reading CSV files!).  He’s not only made them work, and handle many cases that cause other parsers to stumble, he’s managed to make them world class fast (which, to a performance geek like me, is especially fantastic!).
